entry.title: The PetShop project: First day on Ethereum
entry.summary:
The PetShop project: First day on Ethereum
I'm planning to build a simple web3 pet shop application from scratch. Every day I'll try to enhance The project is hosted on GitHub: https://github.com/zhengzhong/petshop Set up a Hardhat project Create and compile a simple token in Solidity Create and run some tests for this contract Deploy the contract to the local Hardhat network Deploy the contract to the Goerli testnet I was basically following the Hardhat's tutorial for beginners. Firstly, create an npm project, install some dependencies, and create an empty hardhat.config.js $ npm init ...
$ npm install --save-dev \ hardhat \ @nomicfoundation/hardhat-toolbox \ @nomiclabs/hardhat-ethers \ ethers \ dotenv ...
$ npx hardhat 888 888 888 888 ‚Ä¶

entry.title: LG‚Äôs latest OLED monitor has a super-quick 240Hz refresh rate
entry.summary:
LG UltraGear OLED Gaming Monitor (45GR95QE). | Image: LG
LG has announced a new 45-inch ultrawide OLED gaming monitor with a refresh rate of 240Hz. The company is calling the UltraGear 45GR95QE its ‚Äúfirst curved OLED display with a 240Hz refresh rate,‚Äù which is notable at a time when most OLED displays (including those with flat panels) are still capped at 120Hz. The company is yet to announce pricing or a release date for the monitor, but plans to show it off at IFA in Berlin next month. Having a higher refresh rate means a display appears smoother and less juddery, and video games feel more responsive to play ‚Äî especially when combined with OLED‚Äôs near-instantaneous response times. Until recently it was rare to find an OLED display with a refresh rate of over 120Hz, but that‚Äôs changed in... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Heroku is removing the free tier
entry.summary: If you are anything like me, you have a few small projects that you are hosting on Herkoku. Read on to learn more about some of the changes that will likely affect you. Heroku is a Platform As A Service (PAAS) "based on a managed container system, with integrated data services and a powerful ecosystem, for deploying and running modern apps" heroku.com. This means that, with a small amount of config, you can get your web app live and available to the world without setting up servers. Heroku offers, what they call, Dynos. These are used to run your code and a small servers to run your Web apps on. Currently Heroku offers a generous free tier so that developers can get their web apps up and running quickly and for free. The only real downsides are not enabling a custom domain and slower cold‚Ä¶

entry.title: How We Built a Serverless Backend Using GraalVM, AWS Lambda and Astra DB (Part 1)
entry.summary:
Introduction
When the pandemic started, we set ourselves a learning goal: develop a backend using only serverless technologies. Initially, we set out to make this happen using technologies we were already familiar with, AWS Lambda and Java. But to spice things up, we decided to add some new technologies to the mix ‚Äî GraalVM to eliminate the JVM Lambda cold start problem, and DataStax Astra DB as our serverless DBaaS. So, we spent a couple of hours per week on building a serverless order processing API using Astra DB and AWS. Due to the pandemic, you could call it a distributed ‚Äúhackathon‚Äù of sorts, in which we had three main challenges: Access Astra DB from within AWS Lambda Write automatic tests for our Astra DB client Set up the Lambda function to use the GraalVM native image runtime I‚Ä¶

entry.title: Put your SQL directly into your HTTP endpoint code
entry.summary: Creating an HTTP web API endpoint by adding hardcoded SQL directly into your endpoint's method is the equivalent of cursing in church. I have worked with software developers who would become physically violent if I told them to do such a thing. However, let's stop and ask ourselves why this apparently is such a bad thing. I really can't see the problem here. Hence, put your SQL directly into your HTTP endpoint code. There are tons of arguments against it, but once you really think about these, few of them makes much sense for most projects today. Once you've started implementing your project, it's highly unlikely you'll ever want to change database implementation from MySQL to PostgreSQL. So the argument of being able to exchange your database implementation is basically mute. Using an ORM‚Ä¶

entry.title: The importance of collaboration, a DevOps pillar
entry.summary:
Remember I talked about the pillars of DevOps, and what DevOps actually is? The pillars of DevOps. What is a DevOps engineer? Michelle Mannering „Éª Sep 27 '21 „Éª 4 min read #devops #devrel #discuss
Well, I wanted to dive a little deeper into the importance of collaboration and why it is a pillar of DevOps. A lot of people hear the word "DevOps" and they immediately think CI/CD. All thoughts center on coding and nothing else. This isn't everyone obviously, but many people believe DevOps is a tool, a platform to help get code deployed out into the world. This is part of it but not the only part. DevOps is as much a cultural change, a mindset, and practices as it is about the tools and products used.
Image: Antonio Janeski via Unsplash Collaborating and working together‚Ä¶

entry.title: Fin PEN: An AI-powered receipt image analysis app
entry.summary:
Overview of My Submission
Fin PEN is an AI powered fintech app used to analyze customer invoice receipt images in realtime, allowing business owners to better understand client spending habits. The app receives customer invoice receipt images in realtime, captures the receipt's data, and analyses the captured results to better understand customer spending habits. Fin PEN's system architecture is split into 3 core units, image, analysis and storage. The app uses Redis' queuing system to receive, track and process requests and RedisJSON to store the analyzed data. Fin PEN's system design looks like below. Fin PEN‚Äôs System Design Architecture:

How I analyze my music directory with Groovy Chris Hermansen Fri, 08/26/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this Lately, I‚Äôve been looking at how Groovy streamlines the slight clunkiness of Java. In this article, I begin a short series to demonstrate Groovy scripting by creating a tool to analyze my music directory. In this article, I demonstrate how the groovy.File class extends and streamlines java.File and simplifies its use. This provides a framework for looking at the contents of a music folder to ensure that expected content (for example, a cover.jpg file) is in place. I use the JAudiotagger library to analyze the tags of any music files. Install Java and Groovy Groovy is based on Java and requires a Java installation. entry.title: My open source journey from user to contributor to CTO
entry.summary:
My open source journey from user to contributor to CTO Jesse White Fri, 08/26/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this When people ask me what I love most about open source, my answer is simple: It's the openness. With open source, the work that community developers and contributors do is in the public domain for all to see and benefit from. I couldn't love that philosophy more. How many people can say that about the fruits of their labor? How many, perhaps 50 years from now, can look back and say, "Check out the code I wrote that day that hundreds/thousands/tens of thousands benefited from." I find that infinitely more exciting than working on software that's hidden from most of the world. I'm fortunate that my job puts me in the middle of an interesting area where open ‚Ä¶

entry.title: JHipster does not use lombok. Why?
entry.summary: After I run the JHipster generator for the first time I realized that the back end implemented with spring boot doesn't use Lombok. So I decided to customize the generated code to use lombok than I realized it wasn't the best way to use JHipster. When I realized how awesome JHipster was I thought that I should change the generated code to be like the one I used to type manually. So I saw the opportunity to create my own blueprint with the following custom annotations: Add Lombok - @lombok Hide comment - @noCodeComment Change the database scheme - @schema Add Id GeneratedValue to entity - @generatedValue(identity) Define column database name - @column(ds_field) Use unsupported types - @newFieldTypeImport(import_class_package_type) and @newFieldType(type) I opened source my blueprint which‚Ä¶

entry.title: Best Practices for Building Reliable APIs
entry.summary: As your APIs scale, the need for making them reliable and robust increases. This article discusses the best practices for building reliable APIs by introducing a special kind of reverse proxies called API gateways. We will look into: Problems with traditional API designs What API gateways are How API gateways improve APIs and Patterns and examples using API gateways But first, what are "reliable" APIs? As a service provider, you might have service-level agreements (SLAs) with your customers, usually quoted in uptime---the amount of time the service is guaranteed to be online and operational. Uptime is a myopic view of reliability. To understand what it means to be reliable, you have to look at the factors that affect uptime. Once you understand these factors, you will be in a better po‚Ä¶

entry.summary:
Often when we are talking about container and docker images the things that comes to mind in terms to deployment is Kubernetes ECS or Fargate Docker Swarm or Docker Daemon Although these are the most commonly used technologies for deployments but for a small set of stateless applications this is comes over with a lot of management overheard. At this point AWS has given the leverage to deploy and build container images on Lambda and run as any simple application. Lets look into building and deploying a DOCKER application using serverless. Pre-Req: Docker Daemon Serverless utility ECR and AWS Login Details Install Serverless Utility npm install -g serverless

entry.title: Elon Musk says Tesla cars will connect to Starlink‚Äôs new cellular-broadcasting satellites
entry.summary:
Soon with satellite connectivity. | Photo by Loren Grush / The Verge
Elon Musk just announced that the upcoming second-generation Starlink internet satellites include cellular antennas for connections with phones from T-Mobile in the US, and potentially other operators as well. Following the event, he responded to tweets asking whether the connections will work with Tesla‚Äôs electric cars, which currently connect to AT&T‚Äôs LTE network. According to Musk, the answer is yes. Yes ‚Äî Elon Musk (@elonmusk) August 26, 2022
He didn‚Äôt go into detail about how it will all work or how much data owners could expect to access from the connections when they‚Äôre somewhere out of reach by terrestrial cellphone towers. Musk said during the event that the satellite-to-cellular coverage from Starlink will be capable of... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: T-Mobile and SpaceX Starlink say your 5G phone will connect to satellites next year
entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
T-Mobile says it's getting rid of mobile dead zones thanks to a new partnership with SpaceX's Starlink satellite internet, at an event hosted by T-Mobile CEO Mike Sievert and Elon Musk. With their "Coverage Above and Beyond" setup, mobile phones could connect to satellites and use a slice of a connection providing around 2 to 4 Megabits per second connection (total) across a given coverage area. That connection should be enough to let you text, send MMS messages, and even use ‚Äúselect messaging apps‚Äù whenever you have a clear view of the sky, even if there‚Äôs no traditional service available. According to a press release from T-Mobile, the ‚Äúsatellite-to-cellular service‚Äù will be available ‚Äúeverywhere in the continental US, Hawaii, parts... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: The new Steam Deck ebook lays out Valve‚Äôs long-term vision
entry.summary:
This is the first Steam Deck, but based on Valve‚Äôs book, it sounds like there will be others. | Photo by Vjeran Pavic / The Verge
On Thursday, Valve released a digital ‚Äúbooklet‚Äù all about the Steam Deck, Steam, and the company itself. Valve says it released the book ahead of the Steam Deck‚Äôs launch in Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, but the book also happens to arrive on the six-month anniversary of when Valve sent the first order emails allowing people to buy their Steam Deck. The 52-page ebook is free, and if you‚Äôre at all interested in Valve or the Steam Deck, I‚Äôd recommend flipping through it. Not only are there a few pages littered with Steam Deck prototypes, but you‚Äôll also be able to read about Valve‚Äôs ambitions for the Steam Deck in its own words. Hello! We wrote a small book about Steam Deck, Steam, and Valve. We're pretty happy with how it... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Instagram tightens default content settings for teens
entry.summary:
New teenage users will be defaulted to a newsfeed that shows less sensitive content | Image: Instagram
Instagram announced the platform is rolling out a feature that defaults accounts for new users under 16 years old to ‚ÄúLess,‚Äù the most restrictive setting for Sensitive Content Control. Teenagers already on Instagram will get push notifications ‚Äúencouraging‚Äù them to opt-in to the heavier filtering on what the algorithm shows them across Search, Explore, Hashtag Pages, Reels, Feed Recommendations, and Suggested Accounts. The ‚ÄúStandard‚Äù setting in Instagram only lets users see some content deemed sensitive, while the ‚ÄúLess‚Äù option tightens the restrictions even further, and the ‚ÄúMore‚Äù option allows users to see more sensitive content or accounts than the default settings. entry.title: The US government got caught using sock puppets to spread propaganda on social media
entry.summary:
Spreading memes and fake news to countries like Russia, China, Afghanistan, and Iran | Photo by Amelia Holowaty Krales / The Verge
While countries like Russia and China have been making headlines for years with their disinformation and propaganda campaigns on platforms like Twitter and Facebook, it turns out that the US and other Western countries have been playing the same game. A recent report (pdf) from social network analysis firm Graphika and the Stanford Internet Observatory has uncovered a series of operations, some covert and some less so, that aimed to ‚Äúpromote pro-Western narratives‚Äù in countries like Russia, China, Afghanistan, and Iran (via Gizmodo). According to the report, Twitter and Meta removed a group of accounts from their platforms earlier this month, citing their platform manipulation and coordinated inauthentic behavior rules. Analyzing the... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: New patent may reveal how Apple could pull off a no-notch iPhone 14 Pro
entry.summary:
The iPhone 14 Pro is rumored to replace the notch with a pill-shaped cutout and a hole punch for a selfie cam. | Photo by Vjeran Pavic / The Verge
Apple is rumored to ditch the notch in the iPhone 14 Pro and Pro Max in favor of a pill-shaped cutout and a spot for the selfie cam, and the US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) has published a patent application that seems to show how the company could do that, according to Patently Apple (via 9to5Mac). The patent application covers several possible variants of a device that combines a camera, an infrared light emitter, and a ‚Äúlight folding element‚Äù that can redirect the IR light. The application describes how a light-folded projector can be used to reduce the footprint of these components, leaving more display area on the phone. The notch currently houses a lot of technology, including a selfie camera, an infrared camera, a depth... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Life Goals OS ‚Äî A guide and template for managing personal goals with Notion
entry.summary:
What does it do?
Life Goals OS is part guide part product. It breaks down what goal-setting is about and how it works. It guides you through a simple workflow to brainstorm, define, progress, review and accomplish your goals. It‚Äôs set up as an iterative system to get better at getting better.
What‚Äôs included?
- Resources and guides on goal-setting based on work of various authors such as Stephen Covey, Bill Burnett & Dave Evans, Naval Ravikant and Chris Bailey - A clean dashboard for your goals which you can orient your existing goal management systems around - Checklists and templates that guide you through the processes of setting and checking in with your goals.
Why did I make it?
It was the scratch-your-own-itch-factor. Well, more than just my own itch. Whenever I ask my team and friends what they struggle with the most it's unanimously goal setting. Wat goals should I set? How do I define good goals? How do I stay on track? As COO and Product Manager at our 40-employee business I landed on OKRs as the goal-setting framework of preference. So, After having tried and tested the system for the past years it felt like the right thing to launch as my first indie-project.
I‚Äôve been eager to start with independent projects for a while now. As ferocious Product Hunt follower it‚Äôs incredibly exciting to be on the launching-end for the first time. I‚Äôm grateful for my colleagues and online-friends who‚Äôve encouraged me to take this step. And, a massive shout out to the Product Hunt community for nurturing such a great launch pad.
In celebration of the launch all Product Hunters get 50% off with code: ph50
I‚Äôm excited to see your feedback and happy to answer any questions you might have! ‚Äù
Discussion | Link

entry.title: It‚Äôs settled: 6.1 inches is the ideal smartphone screen size
entry.summary:
You may not like it, but this is what peak performance looks like. | Photo by Vjeran Pavic / The Verge
I come to you today with good and bad news. The bad news is that small phones are dead. Apple is all but certainly killing off the iPhone Mini this year, and the smallest Android phone I‚Äôve used all year is the 5.9-inch Asus Zenfone 9 ‚Äî quite a bit larger than the 5.4-inch Mini. But that‚Äôs what passes for ‚Äúsmall‚Äù now. Here‚Äôs the good news. We can at long last lay to rest the debate over what‚Äôs the right size for a phone because I just made up an answer: 6.1 inches. All phones henceforth shall adhere to the new, entirely reasonable standard I have invented and come with a 6.1-inch screen. Take the Google Pixel 6A and its ‚Äî you guessed it ‚Äî 6.1-inch screen. Next to the 6.4 and 6.7-inch Pixel 6 and 6 Pro, it‚Äôs downright tiny. It fooled me... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Happy birthday, Linux! Here are 6 Linux origin stories
entry.summary:
Happy birthday, Linux! Here are 6 Linux origin stories AmyJune Hineline Thu, 08/25/2022 - 08:01
4 readers like this 4 readers like this On August 25, 1991, Linux 0.01 was announced. All of us have a story to tell about Linux. I told my story a couple of months ago, but for those who weren't here: My first exposure to Linux was when my grassroots hospice organization moved from paper to digital charting. We didn't have the funding to get something proprietary, but the IT department had Linux set up on our old machine, and we used the GNOME desktop and OpenOffice to start our journey in creating digital assets. I recently asked some Opensource.com authors this simple question: What was your first Linux experience? From VAX to Linux For my junior year of high school, I was shipped off t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Keyframes.app v2 ‚Äî Simple dev tools for keyframes, colors, shadows, & more
entry.summary:
@keyframes are some of the things I use most frequently, so I wanted to build them the way I thought they should be. My goal was to create simple tools that are private, local, customizable, and easy to use, without all the annoying junk like massive ads, popups, invasive tracking, or forced social media integration.
üëæ CSS @Keyframe Animation Editor A tool that gives you a timeline (like movie editing software) to easily create and preview CSS animations.
‚ùê Box-Shadow generator Simply move some sliders to adjust your shadow, add multiple layers, then get the CSS.
üé® Colors Create & convert colors, create color palettes, view color contrast and colorblindness, create gradients, and share your palettes.
‚å®Ô∏è Character codes Search for and easily copy special character CSS and HTML values.
üëã What makes it stand out: ‚Ä¢ It's free - all features. ‚Ä¢ It's private & local - Keyframes only uses Local Storage, and there are no 3rd party trackers or ad networks. It's also open source, so you can verify. ‚Ä¢ The UI is customizable - the theme, font, borders, and behaviors like confirmation dialogues and tooltips can be disabled. ‚Ä¢ Created from scratch - no frontend frameworks or 3rd-party libraries let me get everything just how I wanted it.
So if you're a developer or designer who works with CSS a lot, I hope these tools can be useful and save you some time. I'll be adding more tools over the coming weeks - so keep an eye out!
I'd love to hear any questions, suggestions, ideas for other tools, criticism, or anything else you have to say! ‚Äù
Discussion | Link

entry.title: Using eBPF for network observability in the cloud
entry.summary:
Using eBPF for network observability in the cloud Pravein Govind‚Ä¶ Thu, 08/25/2022 - 03:00
Register or Login to like Register or Login to like Observability is the ability to know and interpret the current state of a deployment, and a way to know when something is amiss. With cloud deployments of applications as microservices on Kubernetes and OpenShift growing, observability is getting a lot of attention. Many applications come with strict guarantees, such as service level agreements (SLA) for downtimes, latency, and throughput, so network-level observability is a highly imperative feature. Network-level observability is provided by several orchestrators, either natively or by using plugins and operators. Recently, eBPF (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) emerged as a popular option to‚Ä¶

‰ΩøÁî®¬†pacmanÔºà‰Ω†Â∑≤ÁªèÂú®‰∏äÈù¢ÁúãÂà∞‰∫ÜÔºå‰ΩÜÊàë‰ª¨‰ºöÊõ¥Ê∑±ÂÖ•Âú∞ÊåñÊéòÔºâ„ÄÇ

‰ªéÂ∫îÁî®ËèúÂçï‰∏≠ÊâìÂºÄÊ∑ªÂä†/Âà†Èô§ËΩØ‰ª∂„ÄÇÁÇπÂáªÂ∑¶‰∏äËßíÁöÑÊêúÁ¥¢ÂõæÊ†áÔºåÊêúÁ¥¢ Spotify„ÄÇÁÑ∂ÂêéÔºåÈÄâÊã©Âêç‰∏∫¬†spotify-launcher¬†ÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂ÂåÖÔºåÂπ∂ÁÇπÂáªÂ∫îÁî®ËøõË°åÂÆâË£ÖÔºåÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÂõæÊâÄÁ§∫„ÄÇ

entry.title: WikiSpaces 3D ‚Äî Explore interesting places from around the world in VR
entry.summary:
@linusgeffarth) and I've been building WikiSpaces on and off last year. But what's this all about?
ü•• in a nutshell WikiSpaces 3D is about enabling people to go places *virtually*, where they couldn't go otherwise (physically), by providing a collection of such places as 3d-scans, "spaces" ü™ê, explorable in VR (yes, also with vr glasses). (3D-scans made with Matterport.) There are already some really cool spaces: from Boeing 747 cockpits to Egyptian temples or the LeBron James Arena!
ü§î but why? Mainly, it's about providing educational value and making knowledge accessible: in the times of the COVID-19 pandemic, students are not able to visit interesting places like museums or galleries; but if said place has been 3d-scanned and shared on WikiSpaces, students can visit it virtually. But it's really about everyone: some of the spaces allow exclusive visits to places you could normally never go to, such as a Boeing 747 cockpit (unless your friend's friend is a pilot of course, ha), or simply places far far away.
üí∞ really free? Yes absolutely! Just like Wikipedia aims to share knowledge for free, WikiSpaces does too. Building WikiSpaces has been possible only because the üá™üá∫ EU has provided generous funding (subsidies) for this project. What about user-submitted content though? All spaces are shared under the CC BY 4.0 license.
üëâ what now? Check out the featured spaces, or scroll down to the explore page and check out a space (or two if you'd like üòù). There are already some really cool spaces, from Boeing 747 cockpits to Egyptian temples or the LeBron James Arena! And then I'd love it if you could spread the word, share a link, and follow me on twitter @wikispaces3d (I'll be a bit more active there soon ü§û)
‚ùì Questions? As away! Looking forward to hearing y'all's thoughts! üôè ‚Äù

entry.title: ProductSearch ‚Äî It's like ProductHunt's search bar, but smart as Google's
entry.summary:
Here's how it works There are a couple of things going on inside that search engine, but I'll try to boil it down to simple points.
‚ÑπÔ∏è We collect product info from ProductHunt using their API ü¶Ä We crawl the internet and look for articles that mention the products from ProductHunt üë©‚Äçüíª We then extract appropriate keywords that are relevant to the product üìú We build the index out of keywords that are collected Note: Our Index size is small, so you might get some irrelevant results. But I've been working hard to scale the index size!
Ranking I've been experimenting with a couple of ranking ideas but one that I've found to be particularly effective is this

entry.title: Depths ‚Äî The bookmark manager made for devs
entry.summary:
How many tech content do you read and save everyday?
For me: there's articles about DevOps, twitter thread about web dev, docs of Kubernetes‚Ä¶
I read and saved 20+ resources everyday. üßê
I tried many tools for archiving resources, but none of them perfectly suit my workflow. So does others in Depths. üôÉ
We hate having to tag resources with #Python or #WebDev then manually adding them to folders every single time. Especially when we got like 100+ tabs opening in the same moment. ü§Ø
That‚Äôs where we thought - what if there‚Äôs a solution that is:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Simple 2Ô∏è‚É£ Fast 3Ô∏è‚É£ Automated
That‚Äôs why we decided to make Depths.
Our goal is to help developers to archive & retrieve knowledge in the easiest way possible. To do this, Depths support:
‚Ä¢ Auto-tagging üîñ ‚Ä¢ Full-text search üîç ‚Ä¢ Estimated read time ‚è≥ ‚Ä¢ Import your current bookmarks ‚¨áÔ∏è ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¶ and more for you to explore!
This Alpha version is the first step of our project to make a better bookmark manager for devs. Our goal is to become the best knowledge base tool for devs on the market. üöÄ
As a small team of 4 working part-time, user feedback means the world to us. Feel free to try it and let us know what you think of it! üíõ
We‚Äôll be here for the next 24 hours to answer your questions. Also you‚Äôre very welcome to come to our Discord server to chat with us! https://discord.gg/MSbqnVzB üëã
P.S. If you followed me before, you'll know the previous product I made on is Savvy, which is also a bookmark manager but it didn't have product-market fit. Therefore we spent months on researching and pivoted it into Depths. And I wrote a blog about the entire process :) https://desmond-hth.medium.com/n... ‚Äù
Discussion | Link

entry.title: 7 sudo myths debunked
entry.summary:
7 sudo myths debunked Peter Czanik Wed, 08/24/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this Whether attending conferences or reading blogs, I often hear several misconceptions about sudo. Most of these misconceptions focus on security, flexibility, and central management. In this article, I will debunk some of these myths. Many misconceptions likely arise because users know only the basic functionality of sudo. The sudoers file, by default, has only two rules: The root user, and members of the administrative wheel group, can do practically anything using sudo. There are barely any limits, and optional features are not enabled at all. Even this setup is better than sharing the root password, as you can usually follow who did what on your systems using the logs. However, learnin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Your guide to DistSQL's cluster governance capability
entry.summary:
Your guide to DistSQL's cluster governance capability Raigor Jiang Wed, 08/24/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this Apache ShardingSphere 5.0.0-Beta version with DistSQL made the project even more beloved by developers and ops teams for its advantages, such as dynamic effects, no restart, and elegant syntax close to standard SQL. With upgrades to 5.0.0 and 5.1.0, the ShardingSphere community has once again added abundant syntax to DistSQL, bringing more practical features. In this article, the community co-authors will share the latest functions of DistSQL from the perspective of cluster governance. ShardingSphere clusters In a typical cluster composed of ShardingSphere-Proxy, there are multiple compute nodes and storage nodes, as shown in the figure below.

entry.title: How I migrated to NetworkManager keyfiles for configuration
entry.summary:
How I migrated to NetworkManager keyfiles for configuration David Both Tue, 08/23/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this NetworkManager was introduced in 2004 to make network configuration more flexible and dynamic. The old SystemV startup shell scripts, of which the interface configuration files were a part, were incapable of handling WiFi, wired, VPNs, broadband modems, and more‚Äîor at least incapable of doing it quickly or efficiently. In a series of articles, I've written about why I'm a fan of NetworkManager and how I've used it. In part 1, I looked at what NetworkManager does and some of the tools it provides for viewing network connections and devices. In that article, I mentioned that NetworkManager does not need interface configuration files for most hosts. Howe‚Ä¶

entry.title: Mentoring as a power multiplier in open source
entry.summary:
Mentoring as a power multiplier in open source Josh Salomon Mon, 08/22/2022 - 03:00
6 readers like this 6 readers like this Many developers struggle with work-life balance. They are overloaded with regular tasks and frequently called upon to solve urgent customer issues. Yet many developers, like me, have ideas they want to promote if only they had time to do so. Sometimes these pet ideas do not make it through the product management feature-selection process. Other times, a developer does not have time to complete the solution end-to-end on their own, yet they know if it could somehow be implemented, the project would benefit. This is where mentoring comes in. Mentorship has many benefits: It helps the mentee's personal development, and it can improve the mentor's self-confidence an‚Ä¶

entry.title: My first impression of GNOME Console on Linux
entry.summary:
My first impression of GNOME Console on Linux Alan Formy-Duval Mon, 08/22/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this New on the GNOME desktop is their terminal emulator application simply named Console. It seems aimed at providing a no-nonsense, stable command-line environment for Linux users. Introducing GNOME Console for Linux
Image by: ‚Äã(Alan Formy-Duval, CC BY-SA 4.0) ‚Äã
The GNOME Console isn't as feature-rich as a lot of other terminals, including the previous GNOME terminal, but I like it and have been using it regularly for the past few months. I enjoy the simplicity of it. I waste time in other terminal emulators configuring fonts, colors, and profiles. Console does have some options and nice integration with the GNOME desktop. I'll start with t‚Ä¶

entry.title: What's your favorite screenshot tool on Linux?
entry.summary:
What's your favorite screenshot tool on Linux? AmyJune Hineline Sat, 08/20/2022 - 03:00
4 readers like this 4 readers like this As the saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words, and while that's not always the case with terminal commands and code, it still holds true for the graphical desktop. Screenshots capture precisely what's on your screen. I love taking them to have a record of who attends meetings, so I don't have to write it down at the moment. Or to capture a bug when doing UI testing. We all take them for different reasons, though, and there are more ways to take a screenshot than you might at first think. I started thinking about screenshots after Jim Hall wrote an article listing GNOME screenshots, GIMP, and Firefox as the ways he often takes screenshots. And yet t‚Ä¶
